ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned Chinese characters (reading and writing), grammar points, lots of vocabulary, and how to speak and listen more fluently.
I learned over two hundred characters, multiple grammar points, multiple phrases, and gained multiple cultural insights.

I developed my proficiency in reading hanzi (up to about 800-900 total after chns 112 and 122), learned more grammatical structures and phrases, and further developed my fluency/clarity when speaking in a conversation. The variety of grammatical structures we have learned up until now has been the most rewarding aspect because I feel that it allows me to develop more fluency with sentences that portray complex ideas.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: I definitely learned the material well, and I enjoyed going to class because I knew it would be worthwhile. Chan laoshi definitely cares about teaching Chinese and it makes me more encouraged and enthusiastic to do well. Weaknesses: it was hard to practice speaking since most of the class is just listening to instruction and grammar points, so i wish there was more interaction
There are not any weaknesses in this classes. The professor is very caring about her students and their engagement and learning in the class.

The biggest strength was absolutely the instructor. Prof Chan managed to keep me engaged for every class, despite doing 4 classes a week remotely with very little motivation for other classes. She was very caring and was understanding when students needed extensions. The lectures were always interactive and gave us many opportunities to engage with classmates in order to practice more natural conversations. The variety of projects throughout the semester (pair dialogue, PSA, ...) also gave many opportunities to thoughtfully integrate all the new things I learned. A weakness would be the courseload, or lackthereof. We always had assignments due, but the quantity of assignments due throughout the week was much lower than chns 112, leading me to practice writing hanzi less. Overall it was more difficult to keep up with learning characters because my self-discipline was a bit lacking this semester. Your mileage may vary!

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Padlets and online activities were great in helping to take advantage of online resources. Breakout rooms allowed for quick discussions and conversations related to the topic.
Virtual engagement was very good because the professor provided a lot of supplementary material outside of class. Moreover, the professor was understanding of this years situation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: yes!! I feel so fulfilled as a Heritage learner because I visibly see the difference in my Chinese, and I feel so proud that I can speak more with my parents and I can watch more Chinese shows. Languages stick with your life much longer than any regular course material, and especially as a heritage learner, it's so important to culture and identity.
Yes. I would definitley recommend you to take this class. You learn a lot and there is a lot of engagement with your classmates. The professor facilitates active learning and good study habits.
Yes, Prof Chan is great and the class is very fun! I imagine once the pandemic over and in-person classes/field trips to chinatown in nyc become a thing again, the class will be even more engaging.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: A combination of supplementary material, in person lectures, tutorial sessions and more.
